Award.AwardTitle: Volumes, Ehrhart polynomials and valuations of polytopes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project proposes research on polytopes, one of the central subjects of geometric combinatorics. There are many aspects of polytopes one can study. This proposal is focused on the volume and number of lattice points of polytopes as well as two tools for connecting these subjects: Ehrhart polynomials and valuations. Based on her previous work, the PI plans to investigate polytopes with the property that their Ehrhart coefficients can be written in terms of volumes or more generally are positive, study the Ehrhart coefficients of k-integral polytopes (a family of polytopes defined in the PI's recent work) from different perspectives, and further develop two methods for volume computations. The PI will also study the intermediate generating function, which is a valuation on polyhedra, and work on generalizing Linke's real Ehrhart theorem to a theory on valuations.

Polytopes are higher-dimensional generalizations of polygons. An important topic of study for polytopes is their volume. Also important are their lattice points, i.e., points whose coordinates are whole numbers. Two tools for studying these concepts are Ehrhart polynomials and valuations. They have connections not only to combinatorics, but also to algebra, algebraic geometry, statistics and number theory. Progress in any direction the PI proposes can lead to either explicit descriptions of formulas for volumes or numbers of lattice points, or better understanding of other aspects of polytopes, and therefore benefits related areas. The proposed research has the potential to lead to new algorithms and applications outside of pure math. For instance, both lattice points counting and volume computations have direct relevance to aspects of statistical sampling, and some of the valuations discussed in the proposal have applications in optimization. In fact, the PI's recent work already leads to a new algorithm for computing volume. In general, these problems are sufficiently accessible that they may be integrated into course material and student research projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: As of September 2017, under the support of this grant, the PI has had five papers published, one abstract published, one paper accepted, two papers submitted, and one paper in preparation. She also mentored an undergraduate student for a summer research project which produced some data for future use as well as a preprint. The most significant work that was done during this period includes work on Ehrhart positivity conjecture of generalized permutohedra, work on Bruns' Ehrhart positivity question on smooth polytopes, work on deformation cones of nested Braid fans, and work on Severi degrees.

Polytopes are basic objects everyone can see in real life, and number of lattice points is a fundamental property of polytopes. Ehrhart's theorem is stated in terms of elementary mathematics, and involve elegant formulas in simple forms.Therefore, the results obtained on Ehrhart positivity problems are likely to be of interest and accessible to a wide range of researchers in different fields and at different levels. 

The PI also expects her work on Severi degrees will have an impact on the field of algebraic geometry. In fact, Goettsche already gave new conjectures on refined Severi degrees based on the results by the PI (and her collaborator).

Broader Impacts:  Polytopes arises naturally in many fields outside pure math such as statistics, economics, and optimization. For instance, both lattice points counting and volume computations have direct relevance to aspects of statistical sampling. Some of PI's work already lead to a new algorithm for computing volumes, and she implemented it with a undergraduate student under the support of this grant. Some data was collected for future use.

Although the origin of Severi degrees is in algebraic geometry which is a very technical field and is hard to explain to people who are not specialized in certain fields, polynomiality results of Severi degrees is easier to understand for polynomial is a simple mathematical concept that everyone is familiar with. 

Results obtained under this grant are suitable for a graduate class. In fact, the PI spent a third quarter teaching topics on Ehrhart polynomials when she taught the graduate level combinatorics at Davis in 2014, and she plans to do so again on a different topic next time I teach this class. The PI already successfully mentored a graduate student (during the period of this grant), and just started working with another one. Finally, the PI used the grant to support her graduate student to attend conferences so that he could be exposed to ideas from other experts in the field.
